description.div: Introduction to contemporary German. Stresses oral and written communication, reading and aural comprehension.

prerequisite.div: GERM 101 or equivalent score on German Language Placement Exam.

description.div: Continuation of GERM 101. Readings on contemporary cultural and social issues in German-speaking countries.

prerequisite.div: Open to juniors, seniors, and graduates beginning their German.

notes.div: Does not apply on the liberal education requirements.

description.div: Rapid course in the essentials of grammar followed by reading of varied types of literary and technical publications. For mature students; also designed to meet the needs of graduates preparing for the German reading examination.

prerequisite.div: GERM 102 or equivalent score on German Language Placement Exam.

description.div: Intensive and extensive reading of moderately difficult German prose, review of grammar, conversational exercises based on the texts.

prerequisite.div: GERM 201 or equivalent score on German Language Placement Exam.

description.div: Continuation of GERM 201. Reading of more difficult texts. Class discussion and reports on supplementary reading.

prerequisite.div: GERM 202 or equivalent score on German Language Placement Exam.

description.div: Systematic composition and conversational exercises.

prerequisite.div: GERM 202 or equivalent score on German Language Placement Exam.

notes.div: Could be take the same time as RUSS 202

description.div: Continuation of GERM 203.

prerequisite.div: GERM 102 or equivalent score on German Language Placement Exam.

description.div: Covers the same material as GERM 201-202 and counts as 201-202 in satisfying the liberal education requirements of the College of Arts and Sciences.

notes.div: Permission for a student to take these courses more than once may be obtained from the instructor if the area of concentration has changed.

description.div: Masterpieces of German literature in translation. Selected texts to be announced in the schedule and the course description booklet.

notes.div: Special topic to be covered in any given semester and credit to be awarded are determined by the instructor.

description.div: Consideration of topics in the area of language, literature and civilization.

prerequisite.div: GERM 202 or equivalent, plus 203 or 204 or 321 or 322 or permission.

description.div: Reading of representative authors of the twentieth century.

prerequisite.div: GERM 202 or equivalent, plus 203 or 204 or 321 or 322 or permission.

description.div: Reading of representative authors of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

course.title: Advanced Composition, Grammar, and Conversation I

prerequisite.div: GERM 202 or equivalent, plus 204 or permission.

description.div: Extensive discussion of advanced grammar; exercises in advanced composition and oral expression.

course.title: Advanced Composition, Grammar, and Conversation II

description.div: Continuation of GERM 303.

course.title: German for Business and Commerce I

description.div: Initiates a special sequence of language and culture study designed for students interested in international business. Introduction to cultural aspects of problems related to the conduct of international business. Focus on specific business language problems, e.g., business correspondence, commercial vocabulary, etc.

course.title: German for Business and Commerce II

description.div: Continuation of GERM 307.

prerequisite.div: GERM 202 or equivalent, GERM 203 or 204, or permission.

description.div: Intensive study of standard German with the aid of tape recordings. Emphasis on articulation and phonetic transcription.
Systematic, chronological presentation of German civilization from the beginning to the present.
Systematic, chronological presentation of German civilization from the beginning to the present.
Study of specific period or problem in German Studies: Interdisciplinary focus. Topic varies.

notes.div: Specific topic to be covered in any given semester and credit to be awarded to be determined by the instructor at that time.

description.div: Language, literature, and civilization.

prerequisite.div: Open to candidates for degrees with distinction, with high distinction, and with highest distinction in the College of Arts and Sciences and to seniors and especially qualified juniors, with consent of the instructor.

course.title: Advanced Syntax and Stylistics in German I

description.div: Advanced syntax and style in their application to composition.

course.title: Advanced Syntax and Stylistics in German II

description.div: Advanced syntax and style in their application to composition.
Phonetics, phonemics, morphology, and transformational grammar as applied to standard German.

course.title: Survey of Medieval German Literature in Translation

prerequisite.div: Permission or GERM 302 for German majors.

notes.div: German majors expected to read the works in German translation and to write their papers in German. Non-German majors read the works in English translation.

description.div: Development of German vernacular literature during the Middle Ages. Include works that represent the philosophical/religious literature, the heroic epic, and the romance.
Grammar to attain reading knowledge of Middle High German/translation of excerpts from a variety of Middle High German texts.

prerequisite.div: GERM 443 or 843 or reading knowledge of Middle High German.

description.div: Reading of masterworks of Middle High German literature in the original language.
Humanism, Reformation, and Baroque.
Representative authors of the Enlightenment, Empfindsamkeit, and Storm and Stress.
Representative authors of the Romantic movement.

course.title: Survey of Nineteenth-Century German Literature I, 1820-1848

description.div: A survey of the major literary currents, authors, works, influences in German-speaking countries in the first half of the nineteenth century, excluding Romanticism, which is treated in GERM 448/848. The main concern of the course will be a careful examination of many aspects of "Biedermeier" and "Das Junge Deutschland," the two major movements of the time.

course.title: Survey of Nineteenth-Century German Literature II, 1848-1900

description.div: A survey of the major literary currents, authors, works, influences in German-speaking countries in the second half of the nineteenth century. The main concern of the course will be a careful examination of Poetic Realism and Naturalism, the two major movements in this half of the century.
Critical survey of the major literary currents from the turn of the century to the end of World War I.

course.title: From the Weimar Republic into Exile

description.div: Critical survey of German literature from 1918 to 1945.
Critical survey of the development of epic and lyric poetry from the beginning to the present time.
Relationship between literature and contemporary thought from the eighteenth century to the present.

course.title: Postwar German Literature: The Literature of West Germany, Austria, and Switzerland

description.div: Critical survey of major literary currents in the West since 1945.
Representative works.
Critical study. Lectures, assigned readings, and reports.

notes.div: Specific topic to be covered in any given semester and credit to be awarded to be determined by the instructor at that time.

description.div: Consideration of topics in the area of language, literature, and civilization.
Morphemic theory and its application to modern German.
Recommended for graduate students in German. Application of linguistic theory to teaching or learning German as a second language.

prerequisite.div: Admission to masters degree program and permission of major adviser

description.div: Braun: Althochdeutsche Grammatik and Lesebuch.
Training in descriptive, comparative, and historical linguistics.
The classical period, Klopstock, Wieland, Lessing, Herder, Schiller, Goethe. Subject to be selected.
Tendencies of German literature during the last 50 years.
Individual research projects on a literary or philological problem in areas not covered by seminars or thesis.

prerequisite.div: Admission to doctoral degree program and permission of supervisory committee chair
